content.description: This ascends a right-angling, tapering crack with about 15 feet of face climbing at the end of the crack to an anchor.
content.protection: Gear to 3" +  2 bolt anchor. Did I need a #5? No. Did I place a #5? Absolutely.
content.location: Climb a wide crack with an aspen tree at the start.

content.description: This has easy quartz climbing with a short slab section at the end.
content.location: It climbs a large, flat face with the only section of quartz on the granite face.

content.description: This is very similar to the other routes on the backside of the Egg. Start with a thinner climbing that leads to amazing jugs towards the top.  I thought the climbing was upper 10 range, but there might be better beta.
content.location: It is the rightmost route on the backside.

content.description: Slab climb past a high first bolt to a headwall. Clip a bolt, and climb the crux over the headwall to more slab climbing to the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus an anchor at the top.
content.location: A high bolt on a slab with a headwall is visible just before the trail along the base enters the trees.

content.description:
Climb through a tree to the first bolt, 30 feet off the ground (the same start as 'Out on a Limb'). Cut right from the bolt to the anchors on the

Unknown 5.5

, with a slight runout to the first piece of protection in a right-angling crack. Finish with some slightly techy slab moves, and lower down past the

Unknown 5.5

.
content.protection: Gear to 1" with Metolius 0 and 00 recommended and a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Use the same start as 'Out on a Limb' directly next to the large pine tree with overhanging branches onto the rock face.

content.description:
This route was named after a good Scottish buddy with a big heart and even bigger forearms that returned back to his motherland. This route tackles the most difficult sustained line up this killer wall. Stickclip the high first bolt (or clip in on the way down from the unknown 5.10 on the right), and engage in some difficult moves to a showstopper crux at the second bolt. Hang on tightly as the sustained remainder of the route will get the forearms' mitochondria to begin fermenting their pyruvate and recycling their NADH in a last ditch effort to synthesize ATP before clipping the chains.

I thought the

unknown 5.11b

on the left was closer to a 5.11a and that this route was a letter grade harder. So, I guess if you think that one was actually 5.11b, then expect this one to feel 5.11c, hence the 5.11 grade. Regardless, great moves up excellent stone will bring a pump to your arms and a smile to your face.
content.location:
It is in between the

unknown 5.11b

and the unknown 5.10 on the beautiful wall on the back side of the Egg.

content.description:
My good friend once said "Make friends with pain, and Aleve in yourself."  No one but me around the campfire could understand him, because of his hard, drunken, Scottish accent. So we just sat there laughing like idiots as everyone else just stared.

This route is a great warm-up for the pumpier routes on the right of this great wall. Start up on the slab to the left to gain the more than vertical, patina headwall above, and finish at its highest point.

So pop some naproxen, or any other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, and get on it.
content.location:
It is the leftmost route on the great wall of the backside of the Egg next to the

unknown 5.11b

.

content.description: This shorter route climbs excellent rock up a very slightly overhanging face, passing through several panels of sheer, blank rock on excellent but pumpy holds. Going left at the crux seems to be the way to go, though you can also go straight up if you've got hops (or wingspan).
content.location: On the far left side of The Egg, there will be a nice looking slab to start the route.
